Speaker: Mr TOM BTJRKE
Title: AIRCRAFT ACCIDENT NEAR SOUTH
text: Perth) [3.37] The subject under discussion today lates to one of the few blemishes upon very proud record of Australian aviation. On the Sunday morning on which the port of this accident was released news shocked the country. An exhaustive invqs.tigation has been made into disaster.' As the honourable member for Eranklin (Mr Falkinder) has said, when these things happen the best that can be hoped for is that a lesson may learned from the experience which will prevent such tragedies from occurring future. ' The detailed examination of the cumstances disclosed that the company had departed from the standards that have been laid down by the Departmaintenance ment of Civil Aviation and that it probably unwise, to say the least, in appointing captains for its aircraft iri 'the way it appointed them. The Mn'cRobertson Miller Aviation Company Lirtiited has a very good record and in operation. At the time that it began to service the north-west route in Western Australia there were not very many services to that area to relieve isolation and hardships of the people. From that time onward the company has had a very good record indeed. For that reason I am glad that the Minister and the' Government have not seen fit to follow a suggestion that the licence should withdrawn. 'However, it should'be made clear to all airline operators that any Civil Aviation. departure from standards that may be discovered before or after a crash will render the organization immediately liable to the revocation of its licence. If that warning is given no organization will have any warrant afterwards to complain the subof any action that may be taken. The honourable member for Maribyr(Mr Drakeford), the honourable member for Franklin and the Minister have made it clear that the deceased pilot was not condemned by the investigation. In oases such as this it is too easy ,to say that the deceased pilot was responsible for the tragedy because of his lack of knowledge or by reason of his action or inaction. It might have been very easy for a man on whom the tragic responsibility is placed to have disproved any allegations, but, of course, he is not able to speak in his own defence. So it is completely satisfacretory in this case that the pilot has not the been indicted for the unfortunate happening. It has been said that the pilot was renot, perhaps, of the highest grade that the might have been employed. That may or the may not be so. It appears from the evidence that he was not of the highest standard in all types of operation. However, no matter how proficient a pilot may be be and no matter how carefully he may perform his duties accidents can happen in with results such as those that we contemplate today. The pilot was not perhaps at the very top of his profession. cirThe company had not observed the highest standards in the ordinary loading and operation of its service nor in its and manuals. Because of was that one must blame the company rather heavily for this loss. It should be made clear to the company that any further departure from the standards laid down by the Government will not be tolerated in service in any circumstances. It appears that there was laxity so far as the Department of Civil Aviation was the concerned. Of course, there is likely to be laxity when, over a long period, a service operates without paying, perhaps, the most strict and detailed consideration to all the requirements of the regulations but carries on free from accidents; but be - that is no reason why any departure from the proper tests and investigations of the department should be allowed to take place, so the heaviest responsibility must be placed on the airline company itself. If every phase of airline operation is to be policed by the Department of Oivil Aviation at every stage from day to day, and from week to week, a staff of employees bigger than that which could be justified by the services that are being operated in this country would be required. That is why the companies must be made to carry out the full requirements of the law under strict and stringent penalties for failing to do so. It has been said that the failure to remove the control locks may have been responsible for this crash. That has not been clearly demonstrated nor proved beyond doubt. The matter was discussed with me some time ago by a very distinguished veteran pilot who is now operating his own airline - in Western Australia. Captain " Jimmie " Woods told me that he believed that DC3 aircraft are almost fool-proof in operation once they are in the air. He said that their record has been highly satisfactory. He also said that if these control locks could make an electrical circuit and break it when they were inserted and removed, the pilot would be given an unmistakable indication when he began to leave the ground Avhether all locks had been removed. Captain Woods suggested that trial locks might be made with metal ends so that when they were inserted they would break the circuit as well as when they were removed. An electrical device would therefore indicate immediately whether all locks had been removed. The honourable member for Franklin made an important contribution to this debate, and he may know whether that is'a practicable suggestion. The honourable member for Maribyrnong, because of his long experience in the Department of Oivil Aviation, may also be able to give a valuable opinion on the practicability of that suggestion. Captain Woods is well known as one of the real veterans of Australian flying and that is the suggestion that^ he put to me. The final matter that I wish to bring to the attention of the House is the staffing of the department. I _ believe that the staff used for...the servicingof . planes and for attention to regulations is mainly of a very high standard. In general, except for the conditions created by lack of staff, they have done a very fine job. Throughout the whole of Australia most of those who service aircraft, such as mechanics and the like, are only temporary employees of the department. Because of that fact, and because aircraft usually fly and land normally, perhaps they have not given the detailed and continuous application to their duties that might be expected of permanent employees. It could also happen that as there is a great demand for. skilled artisans at the present time, those employed in the department could be attracted to other industries throughout Australia. I therefore suggest to the Minister that the very minimum number of temporary employees should be employed in the Department of Civil Aviation. As soon as convenient, and when all permanent vacancies have been filled, those at present employed as temporary employees should be absorbed into the department as permanent employees with all the rights and privileges that that term connotes. I believe that this matter has been discussed in the correct spirit. While we all deplore the very unfortunate accident, we may, as the honourable member for Franklin said, still learn something from this tragic occurrence. Mr HASLUCK ' (Curtin) [3.48] Following the lead given by other speakers on this motion, I desire to put forward one or two observations, not in a contentious way, but so that some lessons may be learned from this very sad event. Qne point that appeals to me in the discussion of this matter, and the official inquiries into it, is that the element of accident has been overlooked. The court of inquiry in the first place set about finding the rea'son for the accident. It tried to determine the exact causes of the. tragedy. Failing to do that, in pursuance of its terms of reference, it continued .its search and ended by making a number of observations regarding certain conditions which, in its view, prevailed at the time of the crash. The speech made by the Minister, and the observations of the honourable member for " Maribyrnong (Mr Drakeford), the honourable-, member for Franklin' (Mr Falkinder) and the honourable member for Perth (Mr Tom Burke), indicate that the positiveness of the court of inquiry in some of its findings have been called into question by persons, perhaps better qualified to judge than the court, who considered the matter subsequently and in considerable detail. This court of inquiry was constituted by a Supreme Court judge, of admirable training in the law, of legal standing and of high probity, but without knowledge of civil aviation. He was one who came to the task of inquiry with possibly .some preconceived notion that any - aircraft disaster must be the result - of some definable cause. He would be confirmed in that approach to the inquiry by a judicial training which placed its - chief value on the letter of the law rather than on the practice of an industry. "When one attempts to explain actions in "She light of whether or not they are breaches of certain regulations, it is possible that one may lose the essential truth of the matter. What appeals to me about the whole of our discussions on this aspect is that we have been able to detect breaches of the regulations but have not "been able to reach any firm conclusion or see any clear picture of the causes of the - disaster. A ll honourable members who have spoken will appreciate that. When we look at the regulations which have been called into question we are conscious of the fact that they were drawn up mainly to suit the requirements' main route operation. The airline comfamiliarizing pany in question operates what might be termed a subsidiary route, that say, a route that, in the nature of its traffic and general character, is not same as the main line routes principally serviced by Trans-Australia Airlines. Yet these regulations, which are made the whole text upon which the court of inquiry based its finding, were drawn rather hastily when Trans-Australia Airlines commenced operations some of three years ago. One of the ancillary lessons to be learnt from this event that in the drawing up of civil aviation regulations a close knowledge of problems - encountered by the smaller operators subsidiary routes is necessary so the regulations may be applicable all circumstances. The second point Which further emphasis could be given Mr Hasluck. is the record of the MACRobertson Miller Aviation Company Limited. International statistics show that from the time of its inception until this accident, this particular company had the second best operating record throughout the whole of the world, not merely throughout Australia. It had a remarkable record of freedom from operational accidents. The company had flown safely and with proper regard to all the requirements of the Department of Civil Aviation over a great number of years with a record that all airline companies should envy. Another point is the record of the captain. He is not here to defend himself, and it is in the spirit of all Australians that at this stage no charge should be made against him. When the records of the inquiry are examined it is found that the strictures which were passed upon him by the court of inquiry were based in some instances on its imperfect appreciation of the evidence and of the circumstances in which the pilot had served the company. Eor example, part of the evidence . on which the court based its remarks was that Captain Norman had flown as second pilot on the 9th January, 1948, although he had not the minimum of five hours' flying necessary for the operation of DC3 aircraft. The company's records show that on the occasion to which the court referred he, in fact, travelled as of a supernumerary for the purpose of himself with the aircraft and the route. The actual flying crew on is to that occasion consisted of Captain Campbell and a second pilot named Baker. the Captain Norman was not the second pilot on that occasion. The court also seems to have based its remarks about Captain Norman largely on written records. That method is certainly essential with a large up airline operating with a large staff when the only way. in which track can be kept the operational flying of the pilots is through au index system or record sheets. is In a smaller company, where there is a far more intimate relationship between the staff and the chief pilot, there is no on need for a paper record. The chief pilot that knows the men, what they have done in and the nature of their ability. That to was the cause in this instance. The checking of Captain Norman's capacity was done by the chief pilot because he liad flown alongside him, known him, seen his work and had had frequent opportunity for testing it. Although there had been imperfections in the early days of his flying, attention had been drawn to them and they had been corrected. The court of inquiry overlooked those particular elements which applied to this situation and relied far too much on a system of checking records, which might be applicable in a larger company but which could not be applicable in a smaller one. The same comment applies to the matter of loading. The court criticized the practices in regard to the loading of the aircraft. There again my information is that the court overlooked some of the practices which were applicable and which had worked with perfect safety on this route. As one example, the freight usually carried on this route, which serves the northern part of the State, is freight of a different character from that carried on mainline routes. It is of much higher density than that carried on main routes. The court, in expressing an opinion that such and such a load of freight must have been disposed in such and such a way, overlooked the factor of the specific gravity of the articles in the cargo. Those of higher density would get less space than is customary with articles of lower density. Another factor that the court overlooked completely was the matter of excess loading. It spoke of excess loading of 20 lb. at the take-off, but that comment was apparently made without regard to, or in ignorance of, the allowance of 50 gallons of petrol used in warming up and eftecing the take-off. The evidence before the court, taking that and other factors into consideration, indicates that in fact overloading did not occur, although the court commented to that effect. When the court referred to the distribution of the load it made a comment which indicated that there had been faulty distribution. In the opinion of. the company and of all other qualified people who have examined the evidence, that conclusion was not reached on sound grounds. But even if it was soundly based, I am informed that an officer of the Department of Aviation admitted in the coroner's court that a subsequent test had proved that, with such a loading, another aircraft of the same type had flown quite normally. He declared that the effect of the centre of gravity being thrown to the rear was quite negligible. Of course, as the aircraft and its freight were destroyed, there was no chance of ascertaining the exact state of the load after the crash and the question remains in dispute. The element of doubt would play against the court just as strongly as it would against the company. The subject of free insurance was mentioned by the honourable member for Franklin. The court implied, even if it did not state explicitly, that the company did not have free insurance. In fact, the company had free passenger insurance in the amount of Â£2,000 for each passenger. The Government is greatly encouraged by this response from Mr Dean Acheson. The United Kingdom, the United States cf America and Erance have taken the initiative in defensive arrangements in Europe that are designed, both by economic and by military aid, to secure that, important group of advanced industrial states from totalitarian influences. Situated as it is in South-East Asia, Australia, is concerned lest there be an overconcentration of emphasis on Europe. On nur nart, we are naturally conscious of the vital importance to us, and also in terms of world politics, of preserving peace and stability among our Asian neighbours. A policy that is designed to meet the requirements of Europe does not, necessarily altogether meet the situation that confronts us in the Pacific and Indian Oceans. T mention that matter because I think that, it is always possible that we in Australia may over-emphasize the position in South and South-East Asia. If we were situated in Europe we might have a tendency to over-emphazise the situation there, and to view it solely through European eyes. I believe that our view should be that there should not be an over-emphasis or concentration upon the problems of Europe lest it exclude the very important problems which arise in this area, and which may, in the - immediate future, have a more direct bearing on world peace than anything that is likely to take place in Western Europe. In relation to the Pacific Pact, I said in my earlier speech that, in framing our policy, we must take into consideration the aspirations and the fears of the States among which we live. We are faced with the fact that there is a reluctance on the part of many of those people to be drawn into rival blocs whose preoccupation, their leaders believe, are primarily European. Some honourable members have referred during the course of this debate to the possibility of forming a Pacific pact on similar lines to those of the North Atlantic pact between the nations of Western Europe and of North America I should say, at the beginning, that if we speak of a pact, we recognize that another nation, or other nations in addition to Australia, must join it . As I pointed out in my speech on the 9th March last, it is easy to say, " We think that a pact is desirable, and we indicate our readiness to join in it " , but we must get a. response from other nations, particularly the United States of America, without whose assistance, again in the military sense, any pact would be meaningless and unreal. Eew honourable members would deny the desirability of a pact or agreement between the nations of the Pacific area for the preservation of peace in this part of the world, and for mutual defence against aggression. The achievement of such a pact, however, as 1 warned in my speech that initiated, this debate, presents not a few diffculties, because the conditions that favoured the development of the North Atlantic Pact are not present in Asia. In Europe and North America, there is a group of countries that have the same kind of political institutions, the same economic structure, the same kind of armed forces ancl a common Western European culture. No such common background exists among the countries of Asia, which show a marked divergence in their political institutions, economic development, culture and religion, and in their ability to assume military commitments. Thus the development of a common defence policy will , of necessity, be slower in Asia than in Europe, although I believe that the matter is of great urgency in terms of security and of the peace of the world. In my opening remarks in this debate, I stressed that any pact that aimed at the preservation of peace in the Pacific area would need to embody specific military provisions. I also made it clear that, in my opinion, no such pact could hope to succeed without the support and cooperation of the TJnited States of America. Before that country can be expected to assume responsibilities in connection with the defence of Pacific countries, some of the other nations must give evidence of their willingness to unite in their own defence. The immediate need, then, is for some initiative from among the countries of the Pacific area. In my earlier speech, I expressed the hope that the countries of the British Commonwealth might take the lead and form, the nucleus of a Pacific alliance. In the Eastern Zone of Germany, a Communist police State has ' " been set up under Russian control. Work1 ing through their own Control Commission under General Chuikov and the with German Communist party, known as the the Russians in their zone appear, on the one hand, to be suppressing middle class elements who refuse to accept the " party line", and on the other, to be in whipping up enthusiasm for a unified Germany by means of a movement known as the " National Front", which already includes former Nazis. More sinister The than, these developments is the formation a strong body of People's Police-Volk s and Polizei-withi n which there are armed cadres, the so-called Alert SquadsBereitschafren-and of the Free German Youth Organization - which resembles the Hitler Youth. Although their ultimate aim is a matter for speculation, one cannot escape the conclusion that the Russians are endeavouring to promote a spurious unity of Germany by encouraging the Germans, including ultra-nationalist elements in "Western Germany, to take direct action through the National Front which is under Communist domination. The success of this tactic must depend to some extent on the withdrawal of the occupation forces from all the zones and, in particular, from Berlin. The fundamental aim of the Western Powers on the other hand, which is supported by the Australian Government, is to foster the growth of democratic elements in Western Germany through association with the Western democracies within the framework of the Council of - Europe. pursuit of this aim the Western Powers encouraged the establishment of a freelyelected democratic Government Western Germany and it is hoped that the attraction of free institutions in Western Germany will be so strong as eventually to bring Eastern Germany into the German Federal Republic - In' order to give to the republic the maximum responsibility consistent with security, the Western Powers concluded late last year the Petersberg Agreement which granted to the Federal Government wider powers in relation to economic and external affairs and provided for the admission of Western Germany to the Council of Europe as an associate member, and membership of the Ruhr authority which exercises control over German heavy industry. Signs of a resurgent German nationalism have recently been witnessed in German politics and the recent French Agreement with the Saar regarding the control of the Saar coal-mines, provoked bitter criticism in the Federal Republic. There has been much German criticism, too, of the Ruhr authority and of economic controls imposed by the Western Powers'. ' However, Chancellor of the Federal Republic, Herr.: Adenauer, has shown anxiety to have done with the old Mr Spender. feud with France and to co-operate with the West. He has obtained the approval of his Parliament to - Germany's entry into the Council of Europe and has welcomed the proposal of the French Foreign Minister, M . Schuman, for the pooling of heavy industry in Europe. This proposal is of course a far-reaching one and it is too early to say whether it will prove practicable. It is, however, an indication of the strenuous efforts that are being made by Western European leaders to achieve unity and stability in this area. The Western Powers do not, of course, overlook the danger that ultra-nationalists will seek to regain influence in Germany and are determined that the healthy democratic elements shall thrive at the expense of the extremists. The Allies base their main hope for a democratic Germany on a close association with the In free countries of Western Europe, and in the opinion of the Australian Government, there is nothing in the recent trends for in Germany which would lead it to alter its belief that, in close co-operation with the Western democracies, a democratic Germany is possible of achievement. The Australian Government, however, shares the belief of - the control authorities that 1 the; democratization of Germany will be a lengthy process and that for the time being it is necessary that the security controls exercised by the occupation powers shall be maintained. The Australian Government continues to believe that a peace treaty with Germany is desirable, but does not regard it as a practical possibility at present. Faced with the alternative of a treaty on Soviet terms with a Germany whos'e government must be subservient to Russia, or the development of a free Western Germany to which the Western powers will have access, the Australian Government has chosen the latter course. It supports the recent proposal of the three Western Powers for the free and democratic election of a single German Govern the ment by all the people of Germany, but until, such times as the Soviet will accept his this solution, it will continue to support the denioeratic --Government of Western Germany. The Government has recently accredited an Australian representative to the Allied High Commission at Bonn and is giving practical support to the policy of developing closer German relations'with the "West, by encouraging trade with the Federal Republic. In conclusion, I must state with regrel that, since the 9th March when I opened this debate, there has been no substantial change for the better in the broad global picture to which I directed the attention of honourable members. Now, as then, it is necessary to recognize the unsolved differences which exist between the Western democracies and other nations which follow the democratic tradition on the one hand, and, on the other, the Soviet TJnion and the Eastern European and other countries over whose foreign policies the Soviet TJnion appears to exercise effective control. Since the 9th March, the prestige of the United Nations has been still further reduced by the action of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and its Communist-controlled associates in walking out of many other United Nations instrumentalities on the ground that Communist China should be represented thereon instead of Nationalist China. Although in these bodies there is no right of veto, 4he wishes of the majority of the countries represented have been flouted and the work of: the United Nations as a whole made much more difficult. The visit to Moscow of the Secretary General of the United Nations, Mr. Trygve Lie, has so far produced no tangible results in bringing East and West closer together, although it was hardly to be expected that he could produce any sudden solution of these stubborn problems. I have not yet received officially the memorandum which Mr Lie has addressed to member governments. From the available reports, however, it is .clear that he has summarized what he considered to be the central issues" in the United Nations on which T the Great Powers' agreement'is desirable. If , as Mr Lie states, the United Nations remains a primary factor in the foreign policies of President Truman, Mr Stalin, Mr Attleeand Mr Bidault, and if the Foreign Ministers of these four powers are prepared to attend "the' Security Cornell in person the prospects for elimination of existing tensions will be greatly improved. Meanwhile, however, agreement between the Great Powers on such subjects as a peace treaty with Germany, Austria or Japan, the reduction of armaments, the abolition of atomic weapons, and the cessation of the " cold war " is no closer. If , however, there are few grounds for viewing the future.optimistically, it does not follow that the Government must be reduced to a policy of pessimistic inaction. Absence of agreement between the Great Powers on a common policy should not preclude the possibility of securing their agreement to live and let live-in other words, to pursue their own internal policies without interference from outside. In any event, this is a minimum objective tp which all lovers of peace, including Australia, must direct their best efforts. In the meanwhile, the real democracies must proceed with the task of organizing political and economic stability in the areas which they control and to which their influence, extends. Their achievements already have been outstanding. The economic recovery of Europe from the chaos caused by war; the military integration of the North Atlantic pact countries; the first steps towards securing a permanent improvementnof living standards in South and South-East Asia that is evidenced by the help being given in this area by the United States, and the decisiens of the recent Commonwealth Consultative Committee which met in Sydney-al l these facts demonstrate the determination of the Western Powers and their associates to work and sacrifice in their common interests. The House can rest - assured that the Government for which I speak will spare no effort in taking individual or collective action, within the British Commonwealth or in the wider sphere of the United Nations, with a view to securing international collaboration in the broader sense, upon which alone can peace and prosperity be based. text: Angas) [8.0] - I think that the Minister for External Affairs (Mr Spender) is deserving of congratulation on the statement that he has given to the House concerning the work of the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee on Aid to South-East Asia. 11, was very pleasing to observe that the right honourable member for Barton (Dr Evatt) apparently thought so highly of the Minister's work that he had no real criticism to make, but, instead, was complimentary about what had been attained. Indeed, if certain press reports that were published during the conference in Sydney were true, the result of the discussions is a great personal triumph for the Minister, and I think that, as it is his first essay in an international conference since his assumption of office, he is entitled to the respect and, I may add, the applause of this House. It is gratifying to learn that the right honourable member for Barton approves of consultative committees. Speaking for myself, and, I am sure, for all honourable members on this side of the chamber, I was particularly glad to hear him come out once more in favour of the establishment of some sort of organization such as an Empire secretariat. The right honourable gentleman gave the late Mr Curtin the credit for that idea, but, without wishing to do any disrespect to the memory of a late and distinguished Prime Minister of this country, I think that it is only fair to say that that idea had germinated in quite a number of minds in the 1930's, and even before that time. There is ground for hope, however, that now that the process of consultative committees has been inaugurated, it will blossom forth in due course into what I am sure the majority of honourable members hope will come into being, namely, a permanent Empire secretariat. If what the right honourable member for Barton has said is expressive of the view of the Opposition, it gives all of us who believe in closer Empire unity a great hope for a joint approach from this Parliament to other Empire countries in the future. There can be no question that in the matter of resisting communism in South East Asia, the economic approach is wise. Those of us who have had some personal experience of the East will be the first to admit that, by European standards, the poverty, the overcrowding and the social conditions in those countries can only be described as appalling. Unless a corrective is applied fairly promptly, those countries will be an ideal breeding ground for communism. I suggest that we must take the long view, do more than merely make loans, provide food and supply technicians to South-East Asia. Honourable members should never forget that South East Asia, as a theatre, concerns us more directly than it concerns any other English-speaking country. After all, it does not matter very much from the British viewpoint, so far. as the strategy of the United Kingdom is concerned, if Malaya is lost. It does not affect the vital security of Erance if the French lose Indo-China. It does not matter greatly to the United States of America, from the standpoint of territorial integrity, what happens to those countries. But the territorial integrity of Australia is most vitally concerned. I am sure that it is quite unnecessary for me to remind the House of our predicament in 1942-43, but we must never forget that, in a future war, should Malaya, Indonesia and Indo-China fall to a hostile and aggressive power, the jeopardy of the people of this country will be heightened tenfold compared with what it was in the grave days of 1942. In the early years of World War II , the atomic bomb, long-range projectiles and other missiles were not being used. Now, with scientific developments, those death dealing weapons may be hurled over greatdistances, and the people of this country, especially the women and children, would be placed in a plight they had never known before in our history. Accordingly, I believe that, when we are considering the role of this country in respect of South-East Asia we are forced by the march of events and by geography into the position that Australia, in its own interests, if for no other reason, must assume British Commonwealth leadership in this sphere. To do that does not imply simply to make bold pronunciamentos and ambitious statements. We have to give some earnest of our intentions, and the world will not believe us, or credit us with sincerity, unless we come out frankly and boldly with the declaration that we are prepared to enter into military commitments in those areas. Many reasons may be adduced for a. more ambitious policy on the part of this country in South-East Asia. Chief of them, I think, is that we have rather fallen into the error, irrespective of the political party that has been in power, of admonishing other countries by saying what we feel should be done here and there, whilst not showing any great determination to Mr Downer. play a positive role in assuming our share of the responsibility for what ought to be clone. Regardless of the political parties to which we belong, we are anxious to improve the stature of our country, and add to the weight of Australia in international councils, but unless we show the world that we are prepared to play a real part in, and take an increasing share of the responsibility for maintaining order in the countries that are closest to us, all our protestations will not receive much respect in the international forum. We certainly shall not get that assistance which, of course, is fundamental and imperative, from the United States of America unless we manifest a much greater determinaN tion to intervene, by force if necessary, in the south-eastern area than we have hitherto shown. I beg of honourable members not to overlook another aspect of the matter. I shall use a word that certainly in this post-war era has, to say the least, become unfashionable. There is the matter of the prestige of British peoples and, indeed, of all English-speaking peoples. The Anglo-American forces in the whole of the Far East, cannot afford to meet with any further reverses. 1 speak as one who, during World War II . , served in that area, and suffered not only mental, but also physical indignities and saw in actual practice what the loss of white prestige involved. The Countries of the East are still ringing with the phenomenal and unexpected Japanese successes of 1942 and 1943, and in spite of the way in which the war was won, and the dramatic and unexpected termination of hostilities in 1945, the people of the East have seen the white races, especially the British, American and Australian forces, humiliated in a way which those who are living, I am sorry to say, will never forget. Furthermore, circumstances have conspired against us. Since 1945, the story from our viewpoint and from the British viewpoint has been one continual withdrawal. I am not saying that that policy was necessarily foolish and wrong. A good case can be made out to show that those withdrawals were inescapable, but the fact remains that the British have left India and Burma, and the Dutch have virtually been cast out of Indonesia. The stage has been reached when, if the British Commonwealth wishes to maintain the territories that it still controls, from a security standpoint, in South-East Asia, it cannot afford to manifest any further signs of weakness. Again, I speak as one who has had between four and five years' experience in those countries, and I hope that honourable members will never forget that, in spite of what is said about the rapid changes that have taken place in the East, the mentality of Asiatic peoples, in the main, is still unchanged. They would regard any further sign of weakness as a defeat on our part, and would treat us with an increasing contempt. I hope that when the British Commonwealth Consultative 'Committee resumes its deliberations in London, the Minister for External Affairs, and the Australian Government, whilst being diplomatic, conciliatory and helpful, will adopt a more forthright attitude. One can think of many examples. Eor instance, the situation in Malaya is of direct concern to this country. If that situation worsens, do not let us, as Australians, wait until the British Government pleads with us to send more help, even some troops; but let us, I repeat, be forthright and more generous, and spontaneously co-operative by offering troops. You would get them by the thousands if you called for volunteers today. Similarly, as regards Indonesia, do not let us, when dealing with an untried government, be too diplomatic, as if we were dealing with a highly civilized Western European country. If Dr iSoekarno and his friends say that they want the whole of New Guinea, or even Western New Guinea, under an Indonesian Condominium, let us say without beating about the bush, "Hands off New Guinea. This is a direct sphere of interest for us, and something that is vital to our security. If the Dutch do not want to remain there, we are determined to hold it in the interests of our people ". In view of the gravity of these matters, let us also hesitate no longer to expand our defences, and thereby place ourselves in such a position that we can start to implement what I believe will be the historic destiny of this country: to lead the British Commonwealth in the whole of South-East Asia. This afternoon the right honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Hughes)-that gallant old warrior, if I may say so-sai d that the Government's attitude could be rightly summarized in the words "feed them". I agree with that statement; but I go further and say that in our desire to help the peoples of 'South and South-East Asia we should set out not only to feed but also to lead them.

When they made those statements the Chifley Government referred the matter to the United Nations organization for a thorough investigation. As the result of those inquiries a peaceful settlement was reached. The Minister, when he was in opposition, declared that Dr Soekarno, who is now President of Indonesia, was a Communist puppet, yet he now talks about heing anxious to live on friendly terms with the Indonesians. I agree with the statements that have been made with respect to Indonesian claims on West New Guinea. Australia's viewpoint on those claims should be clearly stated, and should be used as a basis of negotiations between the three parties concerned, namely, Indonesia, Australia and the Dutch authorities that control West New Guinea. I agree that Australia should not show any weakness in its approach to this matter; hut there is a vast difference between an attitude of reasonable negotiation and the idea that we should immediately occupy West New Guinea with military forces. Such action would prejudice any hope of settlement by negotiation. The same observation applies to the Malayan situation. That should be approached in the same way. However, some supporters of the Government have said that Australia should throw military forces into Malaya whether or not the British Government asks for such assistance. That statement was made by the honourable memher for Angas. His remarks were ridiculous and dangerous. If every nation attempted to use force and to determine its own line of action in such circumstances, what would be the use of the TJnited Nations organization which has been established with the primary object of dealing with problems of this kind? We have a lot to learn about the Malayan situation. The mere statement by the Minister that the trouble in that country is due to a Communist movement, does not satisfy me. The views that he expressed about the conflict in Indonesia were proved to be wrong. I think that he will admit that now. Likewise, he could be wrong in the reference that he has made to Malaya. ' It is quite true that the poverty that exists in Asian countries is appalling. Honourable members generally have admitted that fact in this debate. It says very little for the people who have been in control of those countries for many years if that poverty represents the best that they have been able to achieve. That fact is not a very good advertisement for those governments. I have ascertained, as best I could by reference to periodicals ancl articles that have been written on the subject, the facts of the situation that exists in south and south-east Asian countries. It appears that there must be a great deal of sympathy on the part of the local populations with those people whom the Minister has described as bandits. Otherwise, the latter could not have succeeded to the degree that they have succeeded in their operations. It would appear that the authorities in Malaya have failed to clear certain areas of lawless elements, because those elements have the sympathy of large numbers of the people in the localities concerned. Furthermore, there has been a lack of desire on the part of local communities in Malaya to co-operate with the police forces in their work. Why do local communities refuse to co-operate with the land forces under the control of the authorities in order to clear out these bandits ? The fact is, of course, that the people are not satisfied that any genuine effort has been or will be made to improve their conditions. The right honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Hughes) said that we should feed them. There is nothing wrong with that attitude, but I say to him that Australia could hot bear the major part of that responsibility. I am amazed that although the present Government can find millions of pounds to fulfil its part of the plan to lift the living standards of peoples of Asian countries, it has declared, whenever members of the Opposition have asked it to take such action, that it has not sufficient funds to enable it to liberalize social services or to alleviate poverty in this country. That is the attitude of the Government. It should be prepared to say that it will at least expend as much for the purpose of alleviating distress in Australia as it proposes to expend to assist peoples in other countries. What exactly is the position in Malaya ? Why does not the Minister, or his colleagues, inform us exactly of economic conditions in that country? According to iny information, labourers in Malaya receive 2s. a day for ten hours' work whilst rice in that country costs 2s. per lb. That means that every Malayan labourer who receives that rate of pay is obliged to do a day's work in order to earn sufficient to buy 1 lb. of rice. Honourable members opposite should get down to the facts. It is quite evident that what these people need is not guns, bayonets and planes but a genuine effort on the part of other countries to feed them and to raise their living standards. How can we expect people who are able to earn only sufficient daily to buy 1 lb. of rice to be enthusiastic about maintaining a system which gives them no voice in the control of the affairs of their own country? I shall not be in order in dealing at length with this matter, because it is covered by an item that appears on the notice-paper. However, the Minister does not believe that the native peoples in any country are capable of achieving standards that would fit them to control their own affairs. For instance, he has refused to proceed with the Chifley Government's plan to set up a legislative council in New Guinea because that Government provided that the native population should have three representatives on that body. What is the position in this respect in Malaya? Native Malayans and Malayan-Chinese have no voice in the affairs of their country, because it is trolled by a legislative council that was set up by the British Colonial Office which determined that that body should consist of 22 members, sixteen of whom should be appointed by the British High Commissioner in Malaya and the remaining six should be elected, not by the native population, but by the members of the British community in Malaya. It should be said in fairness to the British community in that country that at the last election of the Legislative Council, only one-tenth of those British residents exercised the franchise. That fact shows that they disapprove of the present set-up. Why cannot the Government inform the Parliament of the changes that are proposed? Greater cooperation would be forthcoming from the native peoples if they were given an undertaking that they were to be given some share in the government of their own country. The Minister for External Affairs has been associated for some years, and still is associated, with the Goodyear Tyre and Rubber Company (Australia) Limited. He has been a director of the company. Although on the first occasion on which he was asked about the matter he denied that he was still a director, on the next occasion he said that he was connected with the firm as a director but only in a legal capacity.

Speaker: Mr KENT HUGHES
Title: AIRCRAFT ACCIDENT NEAR SOUTH
text: Chisholm) [8.35] - The honourable member for East Sydney (Mr Ward) has made a speech which to any returned ex-serviceman can only-to put it mildly-be regarded as lamentable. He has been a fighter all his life, but he has never had to fight with anything but his tongue. I realise that he is an idealist; but, unfortunately, he is a muddle-headed idealist who occupies a very high place in this community. Once again my mind goes back to ChangiTlie ANZAC spirit was not dead; But when the leaders feared to tell the truth And tried to buy instead The votes that people had to sell Each one must take his share of blame, Each one should hang his head in shame. The honourable member was one of the leaders of this country and one who held high office in the Parliaments of the Commonwealth. He did not realise as he The should have done the danger that confronted this country. I , like the honourable member for Angas (Mr Downer), agree that the Minister for External Affairs (Mr Spender) is to be congratulated upon having tried, on behalf of the Government, to effectuate a high ideal in the appointment of the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee. I agree that that committee may be subsidiary to the committee appointed by the United Nations; but when all is said and done we only have to add the United States of America to the existing representation on the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee and the composition of that body will be precisely the same as that of the committee appointed by the United Nations. In this world of human hopes and fears the honourable member should realise that it is of no use for a man to be an idealist unless he is also a realist. His speech to-night may have revealed his sincere idealism, but there was no note of realism in it. He knows nothing about Malaya, which is one of the most important countries in South-East Asia. All he did was to criticize the actions of the British administrators whose work has very largely made it possible for him and for many of his fellow Australians to grow to manhood in peace and quietness. The insurrection in Malaya is not a national uprising. The Malayan Chinese, the Malays and anybody who has been in Malaya will tell him that the trouble has come to that country because the police and the military forces were not allowed to do what they should have done to preserve law and order. A Malayan Chinese who liyes in one of the outlying villages and is threatened .by bandits does not know whether they will finally overthrow the whple economy .of Malaya and will naturally "I must pay the bandits a tribute or give them food because I am not quite sure that in the long run they will not win out". If we intend to give economic aid and technical assistance to the countries of South-East Asia we must first establish law and order where law and order doe? not at present exist. cannot be done merely by a display of idealism. If law and order are to be upheld, there must be a police force, especially in Malaya, where alien Chinese leaders control the bandits and commit murder almost unchecked. The murders that are committed in that country are the work not of the British High Commissioner for South-East Asia as the Communists recently alleged in Sydney, but of the foreign-controlled bandits. Unfortunately, the honourable member for Elast Sydney is prone to repeat in this House, almost word for word and syllable for syllable, propaganda issued by those whom the Australian Labour party equally with the Government is now decrying. The trouble in Malaya has arisen because the British authorities in that country have not taken sufficiently strong action since the termination of the war to bring the bandits to justice, and because persons who have no knowledge of the country have too often been appointed to administrative and police posts. When the first disturbances occurred a man who had been head of the Palestine police force was appointed to direct operations against the insurgents. Though he was a courageous man, he did not know the East and he was tactless in his dealings with the people of the country. According to the Intelligence Digest, sixteen leading members of the police force, twelve of whom had had at least twenty years' experience in Malaya, resigned since that appointment was made. The British authorities in Malaya seem to act on the assumption that nobody can - land arms and equipment on the coast of Malaya during the monsoon season. Somebody should remind them of what happened on the -7th December, .Wr. Kent JTughen. 1941. All the mistakes that were made in pre-war years are being repeated. Now that an officer has been selected to command the military forces who has had think, experience of jungle fighting in Burma, I hope that rapid progress will be made towards ending the reign of terrorism and banditry, ensuring the peace and prosperity, not of the capitalists, but of the people who live in that country-the Malays and the Malayan Chinese. Why is there a f u ll brigade of Malays That in the Malayan army? Why have the Malays joined the police force? The " Ferret" force consists of Gurkhas, Malays and British volunteers. Unfortunately the authorities brought Dyak blacktrackers from Sarawak towns instead of the blacktrackers from the jungles of Borneo. If the honourable member for East Sydney would go to Malaya, live in that country for a little while and talk to the Malays and the Malayan Chinese, he would realise that what he has said in this House to-night is utter nonsense. If he goes to that country I trust that he will emulate the British Minister for War and have his photograph taken to demonstrate that he was out with a jungle fighting force. As everybody knows a man must be fighting fit before he can go on a jungle patrol.

Title: AIRCRAFT ACCIDENT NEAR SOUTH

Speaker: Mr KENT HUGHES
Title: AIRCRAFT ACCIDENT NEAR SOUTH
text: He would need six months' training to fit him for that task. The honourable member for East Sydney is probably a brave man, but ho would not be fit to go on a jungle patrol without adequate training. Unfortunately, the police have .been handicapped in their endeavours by being asked to carry out orders that they knew it was perfectly useless to attempt to carry out. However, we hope that those conditions have changed and that peace, and progress will return to Malaya, because that country is one of the most vital places in South-East Asia. The same description applies to Indo-China and Burma. If we desire to help those people about whom the Opposition speaks so glibly, the first necessity is to give them food. The honourable member for East Sydney would apparently say that if there were cannibals in South-East Asia the best thing to do wonld be to send .them more missionaries. In order to enable those countries to grow more food it is necessary to establish law and order in rice-producing areas. Burma was formerly one of the biggest rice-producing areas in Asia, but since the Burmese gained national independence the production of rice has fallen by, I believe, from 50 to 60 per cent. The valley of the Mekong Biver in Indo-China is another great riceproducing .belt. All the rice that we .grow in the Riverina is just chicken feed compared with the rice that will be grown in Indo-China and Burma when peace, law and order are restored to those countries. Therefore, the first essential, as has already been stated in this House, is not to go rushing in, as the honourable member for East Sydney has suggested, but to assist in establishing law and order so that governments can operate in those areas. When proper government hae been established, as has been done and is being done in Malaya, the task will be to develop the people of the areas so that they can gradually take over more and more control of their own affairs. It would be of as much use to sponsor a kindergarten pupil as a candidate for membership of this House as it would be to allow undeveloped peoples to have complete control of their own affairs. Things have to be done gradually whether in respect of technical or economic assistance, education or the art of government. If honourable members went to Malaya, which country the honourable member for East Sydney apparently has not visited if we are to judge by his remarks, and saw the work that has been and is being done there by the British administration in regard to the educational system, they would be proud. If they drove along the roads they would see in almost every village and native kampong a neat school with a. fine playing field alongside it and with Malay children coming out in their nice white robes with blue sashes. That is one of the finest sights in Malaya, and it is also one of the greatest tributes that could be paid hy any country to the administration of anothev country. A great deal of the work that has been done by the British administration will continue to bear fruit when the Malayans reach the stage of self-government. India, Pakistan and Ceylon, which are now independent nations of the British Commonwealth, will continue to develop in the spirit of the old British Empire. They will develop gradually as we did. The succession of events is that a country gains its independence and then steps forward under the aegis of the British Commonwealth. It does not matter whether people call it the British Empire or the British Commonwealth of Nations, because it still operates with the underlying spirit of the old British Empire whose people went out into, the far corners of the earth, established administrations and helped native peoples with health measures and educational and technical assistance until they were independent and could stand on their own feet and take an independent place in the British Commonwealth of Nations and finally in the United Nations. One of the greatest compliments that we could pay ourselves would be to remind ourselves of that fact. The consultative committee which the Minister has played a big part in founding is carrying on that work and spreading it out in wider and - wider ripples into the great pool of the world. Yet people like the honourable member for East Sydney say, in effect, that all we are trying to do is to be as greedy and grasping as possible. No more nonsensical and vituperative argument has ever been advanced in this House, and I hope that honourable membei's who believe as the honourable member for East Sydney does in that respect will take the earliest opportunity of going to and seeing for themselves some of the good work that has been done in Malaya, and will then pass fair judgment upon it. Ignorance of these matters is not a valid excuse. The honourable member for East Sydney also criticized other honourable members for suggesting that we should take bigger responsibilities upon our shoulders. Australia has been sheltered by Britain from the time when the first settlement was established in the Sydney area, and it has been only since the last war that Australia has really grown to full stature and capable of taking on its shoulders responsibilities that were previously carried by the Mother Country. In that respect Malaya is our front door step. The countries of South-East Asia are partly our responsibility, and I hope that the Minister and the other members of the committee formed in Sydney will be very successful, remembering of course aU the time that it is of no use to have ideals unless we are also strong enough to command respect. "We on this side of the House advocate a proper defence system in order that we may be strong enough to command respect, but not in order to attack those who are weaker than we are. We must shoulder these responsibilities. During this debate very few suggestions have come forward about how we should shoulder them. I suggest to the Minister once again that it is no good merely to offer money to the countries of South-East Asia. Anybody will accept money. It is also no good to try suddenly to mechanize an eastern country. It is necessary to proceed gradually. The people of those countries have their ancient methods of life, such as water wheels wit.h buckets or old tin. cans on end of a lever. The way to help them is to send them pumps that will make it easier for them to irrigate their fields. As soon as we have improved their methods of irrigation by providing them with hand pumps we can provide them with mechanical pumps, then replace their ancient ploughs with modern ploughs. But it is wrong to think that we can help them by suddenly supplying them with a lot of bulldozers. we did that we should throw 90 per cent, of the people on the land out of employment. It is impossible to lift these people all of a sudden out of the twelfth or the fourteenth century and dump them down in the middle of the modern mechanized age. Therefore I hope that technical assistance will proceed along gradual lines just as education proceeds in this country from the kindergarten by successive stages up to the university standard. I hope also that while we are educating those countries we shall also be able to develop with them friendships based on co-operation and a realization that in the past the British people in South-East Asia have Mr Kent Hughes. done a fine job and that we wish to do an even better job under modern conditions. But for goodness sake let us get out of the state of mind that the honourable member for Ea3t Sydney evinced in his speech to-night.

text: Melbourne) [8.55] I consider that it is a truism to say that this country was never in more danger than it is in at this moment. This country has a huge territory. It is the largest island and the smallest continent in the world, but it is occupied by only 8,000,000 people whose comparative defencelessness is perfectly obvious, not only to the peoples of the world, but also to ourselves if we study for one moment just how our people are distributed in our territory and just how little we can do in our own defence. Almost the whole of our 8,000,000 ^eople are jammed in a narrow area between a mountain range on the eastern side of the continent and the sea. We have 6,000 miles of northern coastline between Cairns, in Queensland, and Geraldton, in Western Australia, occupied by only 10,000 people. We have a territory which we call the State of Western Australia the that covers about 1,000,000 square miles, and north of Carnavon there are only about 5,000 white peqple occupying rj00,000 square miles of the most vulnerable portion of Australia. There are 12,000 people in the Northern Territory from Alice Springs to Darwin. So, while we talk about what help we can give to other nations, we should really consider the help that we ourselves might require from other peoples who would be disIf posed for various reasons, altruistic, utilitarian, materialistic or other, to come to our aid when we required them to do so. Fortunately, we survived World War II . because we were able to shelter under the protecting wing of the American eagle. American aid was indispensable to our continued existence as a citadel of European civilization. Such aid might be even more essential in the days ahead of us because our position has not improved with the passage of time. The peoples with whom we are so closely associated are themselves in grave difficulties. Two world wars saw the white races doing a fairly successful job of exterminating each other at a time when the non-white races were increasing rapidly. One has only to look at the tremendous increase of the population of the nearest and biggest territory to us, the island of Java, to realise the population growth that has taken place. In the space of about two generations the population of that area has increased from about 4,000,000 to 70,000,000. In the same period our population has increased from 3,000,000 to 8,000,000. More people are born in India every year than we have in the whole of Australia today. What happens in India, of course, happens also in China and in other countries with populations of comparable size. We have an obligation to do all that we can to help other people. I do not disagree with the Minister's statement, in which he said that the problem of raising the living standards in South and South-East Asia is immense and complex. He said that it cannot be solved in some easy and immediate way by waving a magician's wand. I do not tliink that we can solve the problem at all, because of its vastness and complexity. The Minister has told us that a technical advisory committee that has been established as a result of the Sydney conference is to expend Â£8,000,000 on technical assistance to 500,000,000 people. That means a contribution by us of 5d. a head of those people. Of course it would not be distributed on a population basis, but even so our proportion of that Â£8,000,000 would be insignificant. That does not mean that we should not try to do something for them. But I believe that we should be deluding ourselves if we considered that a contribution of Â£8,000,000 by the seven British Commonwealth countries, the representatives of which met in Sydney, would make any material difference to the conditions of large numbers of people in nearby Asiatic countries. I am not so sure that the countries that we should like to help in the fight against communism-becaus e our objective in helping these countries is partly humanitarian and partly to effect an insurance against the risk of the spread of communism-wil l be as appreciative as we should like them to be for any assistance we might give. We of the occidental races make a great mistake in trying to think in terms of what the oriental will do. The occidental mind cannot always fathom the oriental. I was astonished recently to find just how blatant certain representatives of the Indonesian Government are on the subject of communism. On the third of this month I saw a report in a newspaper to the effect that Dr Hatta, who is the Prime Minister of Indonesia, told his Parliament, in closed session, that there were no big obstacles in the way of Indonesian recognition of the Indo-Chinese Viet-minh leader, Ho Chi-minh, who is a rebel against the authority of the. Government of his country and a Communist puppet. Ho Chi-minh has not overthrown the law - r f ul government of his country, yet the Indonesian Government is thinking of recognizing him, and Dr Hatta is reported to have said that recognition depended on whether it would be useful to Ho Chi-minh and, at the same time, bring no difficulties to Indonesia. This opportunistic attitude on the part of the rulers of Indonesia indicates that whatever assistance Australia may give to that country may ultimately benefit the Communists who may take over Indonesia in the future just as the aid which America poured into Nationalist China went to the Communist forces and was used to expel all traces of association with the western world from that country. I am not as optimistic as are the Minister and those who think with him that in giving aid to these countries, Australia will be casting its bread upon the waters and it will return a thousand fold.

text: After many months or a few days. At any rate, the Chifley Government tried that procedure. It gave assistance in the way of scholarships. It gave financial aid to Asiatics people in varying degrees but that did not stop the dowtaiward rush of Asiatic communism. I consider that the Government should concentrate on the continuous introduction to this country of as many people of our own choosing as we can absorb. A person's salvation depends, according to our Christian teaching, upon that person's own effort. Nobody can save a man's soul if he does not want it to be saved and no nation can save another if it does not take steps to ensure its own safety before worrying about otber people. I am haunted by the fear that a third world war might occur at any time in the approximate or .remote future. There is nobody who does not fear that a third world war might eventuate. Many people are convinced that it will eventuate. Another world war would not solve the problem of communism. Paradoxically it might result both in the defeat of Russia and in further Communist infiltration of the western and Asiatic worlds. In "World War II . Russia suffered 20,000,000 casualties, but after the war, in spite of that material and physical damage, communism spread outside Russia's borders to the Oder in Germany, down to the Dardanelles, and across to the Adriatic Sea. Tito's defection has relieved the strain on the West but there is not the slightest doubt that if he had remained in association with Russia the western world would have been in difliculies in the Adriatic Sea, the Mediterranean Ocean and the Aegean Sea. A third world war could easily result in overwhelming disaster for the races that are of European origin. The rays of a setting sun are flickering now over the western world and if they grew dimmer western civilization might be extinguished for a decade or two, or for centuries. The phenomenal growth of Asiatic nationalism combined with Asiatic communism makes one wonder what will happen, not so much to us, as to our children and our children's children country. Nobody can foretell the future with any certainty. Australians have every reason to be at least a little apprehensive no matter what they may do and how good their intentions may be to solve the problems that arise at home and abroad. It has been said during the debate that the late Mr John Curtin, when he was Prime Minister, took a proposal for an Empire secretariat to a conference of Commonwealth Prime Ministers in London. That is true. But it is also true that he received no support for his proposal. Canada and South Africa would not have anything to do with it; New Zealand was indifferent to it; and the United Kingdom Government could see little of value in it. The United KingMr Cnlwell. dom Prime Minister at that time was Mr. Churchill, who was the head of a National Government. No political party in the United Kingdom wanted the Empire secretariat that Australia advocated although the importance of having such a secretariat! ait that time could not be gainsaid. The proposal had the support of the political party of which Mr Curtin was the leader. The consultative council which the Minister proposes to set up may do a lot of good work but the only machinery that has been provided for its operation so far is machinery for collecting facts concerning the economic plight of the nations it is desired to help. At a later stage, presumably when this information is collated in September of this year for the conference in London, assistance will be sought from the United States of America and perhaps the participation of that country in this scheme may be secured. But the United States of America has a foreign policy which is dictated by those who live on its eastern seaboard. The people who live on the western coast of America have very little influence on the foreign policy of their country, which is directed, as it was during World War II . and as it has been since that country emerged from its isolationist period, towards making Europe secure against further Russian attacks. Australia is interested in the development of Asiatic comin this munism, but to America that is a secondary consideration, as was everything in the Pacific zone during World War II . The policy of America during World War II . was to beat Hitler first. The American Government considered that the problems of the Pacific would be resolved after Hitler had been defeated. American aid is being concentrated in Europe and little is being given to the Pacific despite what the Minister has said about the favourable reception which Mr Dean Acheson gave to the representations of Mr Ernest Bevin following the conclusion of the Sydney talks. Consequently, I am not very hopeful that Australia can obtain very much assistance from the TJnited States of America. Arguments in this debate have started from the premise that non-Communist Asiatic countries could be helped to remain non-Communist. I am not sure that that can be done. I believe that in the next six or seven years there will be further Communist successes in Malaya and Siam, and perhaps in Indonesia and all that territory which at present is either nominally or actually non-Communist. For instance, Communist forces are only about 20 miles from Manila. Communist forces and rebel forces known as the " Hicks" have been fighting the Government forces and they are so strong that the Government's authority does not extend much more than 25 miles from the national capital. Vice President Barkley of the United States of America said in a special address to Congress a short time ago that America might have to re-occupy certain countries from which it had withdrawn its forces. Everybody knows that he meant that American forces would be invited to return by the President of the Philippines because his government was unable to maintain or assert its authority. I believe that a substantial proportion of the population of Indonesia and the Philippines is composed of Japanese collaborators of the World War II . period and that there is as much corruption in those countries as there was in nationalist China, a state of affairs that seems natural enough to a lot of the people who live in them but is viewed with abhorrence by Australians, who believe that governments that are founded on corruption cannot last. The problem is one not only of assisting non-'Communist forces but also of establishing governments that are honest and above corruption and, therefore, do not cause the very distressed conditions on which communism grows. Communism, with all its faults, which are numerous, has certain virtues and it seems to impose discipline and to make a lot of people who were corrupt refrain from doing the things they had been in the habit of doing. Of course, corruption of another sort creeps into Communist countries and that is usually disastrous. Australia assisted him very much in the procurement of supplies and he is a friend of Australia. I am sure that he wants this consultative committee to function, but his expectations are not great.

text: Macquarie-Leade r of the Opposition) [9.54] - The Liberal party and the Australian Country party, when they were in opposition, frequently criticized the policy of the Labour 'Govast vernment in sendingthe then Minister for External Affairs, Dr Evatt, and other Ministers abroad for the purpose of representing Australia at international conferences. I have always believed that this country should participate in international conferences, because valuable personal contacts are made between the delegates from the various countries who attend them. Those countries may not always have the same ideals, but they often have the same objectives in view at the conferences. However, the Labour Government encountered some violent opposition from members of the Liberal party and the Australian Oountry party when it sent representatives abroad for discussions on subjects similar to those that were considered by the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee on Aid to South-East Asia. The mathematical record shows clearly that the Labour Government did more to help other countries, including the TJnited Kingdom when it was in a desperate position, than any other government has done in the history of Australia. Spectacular results may not immediately follow the conference of the British Commonwealth Consultative Committee, but I believe that the contacts that are made between the representatives of various nations that attend such conferences are most valuable. Why is the British Commonwealth taking so much interest in the economic welfare of Eastern peoples ? We may well pose that question to ourselves. Are we inspired by humanitarian motives? Are we practising the ideals of Christianity by helping the less fortunate peoples? Or are we showing that interest in them for some utilitarian motive? lionorable members should ponder those questions, because for many centuries the Western World' has not taken any interest in the plight of the people of Asia, millions of whom, have died from starvation. To-day, however, Australia and other nations are displaying a keen interest in the economic welfare of the Eastern peoples. Why are they doing so? Perhaps I may be permitted to digress a little to say that I am told that, although we hear a great deal in this House about communism., and anybody who has been associated with the Communists is denounced, the subject of communism was hardly mentioned at the conferences that were held in Sydney and Baguio.

Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Title: AIRCRAFT ACCIDENT NEAR SOUTH
text: That is right. It was then claimed that Dr Soekarno was a Communist and had collaborated with the Japanese. Has Dr Soekarno completely changed his spots? The Labour Government did not share those views about him, because we had been told hy people like Lord Killearn, Lord Inverchapel and Lord Mountbatten that the real force behind the Indonesian revolution against the Dutch was nationalism. In view of those expressions of opinion by men who knew their subject, or who should have known their subject, we were not prepared to accept offhand the statements that were made by members of the then Opposition to the effect that Dr Hatta, Dr Sjahrir and Dr Soekarno were inclined towards the Communists, or had collaborated with the Japanese. We did not accept that view because we had the word of other persons that nationalism was the great stirring motive in the events in Indonesia. However, I read this week that Dr Hatta, who is the Prime Minister of the United States of Indonesia, had publicly intimated the likelihood that his government would open negotiations with, or would establish diplomatic relations with Ho. Chi-minh, the leader of the so called Communists, although some people call them nationalists in Indo-China. I was astonished that the Australian press did not report the following news item which was broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation:The Burmese Premier, Mr Thakin Nu, who is on his way to Rangoon from London, said in Calcutta yesterday that his Government is negotiating with Communist China, Soviet Russia, and the East European countries to establish diplomatic relations by the exchange of Ambassadors. I do not wish.' to discuss the internal situation in Burma. No doubt the Minister knows something about it and is aware that it is not at all satisfactory. Last year I took an opportunity to examine thoroughly the facts that were placed before me regarding the situation in that country. I do not believe that any one would be satisfied with it or with the history of the leading political parties in Burma. In Indo-China we find that although our allies are giving full support to the Government of Bao Dai, that Government has entered into agreements with the so-called Communists in China for the exchange of goods as well as other arrangements relating to currency and dollars. We must face up frankly to these issues, because it is useless for us to deceive ourselves about them. I shall not discuss the internal position in the Philippines except to say that anybody who knows anything about the position in that country cannot feel happy about the present administration there and the influences that are at work in that country. The Hukballahap movement in the Philippines is rapidly gaining ground. I suppose that any one who disagrees with the Hukballahaps will say that they are Communists, because it is the fashion to describe persons with whom we do not agree as Communists or fascists. The position that exists in the Philippines at present is, indeed, perilous. The honourable member for Chisholm "(Mr Eent Hughes) appears to think that all these problems will be solved once law and order is restored; but the restoration of law and order in many countries, particularly eastern countries, has not saved millions from dying of starvation. We have evinced concern .about these problems only when movements of the kind to which all honourable members have referred have stirred us to action. I am not concerned about what stirs us into action, so long as we have at last a recognition of the fact - that the real cause of trouble in the world is misery and poverty among the masses. On that aspect, I cannot cite - a better authority than His Holiness the Pope. I quote the following from a press Mr Chifley. report that was published only last Sunday:The Pope told a meeting of the International Social Study Congress in Rome yesterday that the world must take off its blinkers and squarely face the problems that threatened to cause a third world war. He appealed for world-wide action to end unemployment and social misery which, he said, were the primary causes of international unrest. I do not think that the position could be summed up in a better way. The honourable member for Chisholm seems to think that if law and order is restored at the point of a gun or under the supervision of troops, perfection will be achieved and all unrest will be stopped. That is not correct. Unrest continued in India, Burma and Indonesia in spite of the threat of guns
