Speaker: Mr CHIFLEY
Title: AIRCRAFT ACCIDENT NEAR SOUTH
text: I shall deal with the situation in Malaya about which the honourable member for Chisholm and the honourable member for Hume (Mr. Charles Anderson) had something to say. Last year I had the opportunity to travel through Johore State and to talk to the many people there. I was told by persons in authority in that region that prior to the outbreak of the recent war there was complete exploitation of the rubber tappers in Malaya. Any one who requires physical evidence of the misery that exists in Malaya need only visit Singapore and see the palaces that have been built, since the end of the war, in one section of that city and in another section, Chinatown, the indescribable misery in which hundreds of thousands of people are obliged to live. That evidence is irrefutable. What is the problem in Malaya? The honourable member for Chisholm said that many Malayans were being stampeded into supporting the terrorists. How does he account for the fact-and the figure is official-that 500,000 Chinese in that country have squatted on land that does not belong to them ? Nobody induced those Chinese to break the law in that way merely by intimidating them. In the Philippines 99 per cent, of the land is owned by only 1 per cent, of the population of that country. The fact is that half the population of Malaya, including Singapore, is Chinese who are antagonistic to the Malayans, and vice versa. Between those two sections are sandwiched from 600,000 to 700,000 Indians. Beal peace will never be established in Malaya unless a government is formed in that country which will bring together those sections to work in harmony for their common good. Of course, it is useless to argue that the Chinese in Malaya are not more industrious, intelligent or commercially minded than the Malayans. Something must be done for the less fortunate sections of the people in that country. I am entirely in sympathy with any action that the Government proposes to take for the purpose provided that it be taken with the right motives and not for purely material motives. I agree with the view expressed by Pandit Nehru that the battle against communism, or any other " ism" will not be won with guns, that it can be won only by capturing the spirit of the people whose lot we are trying to improve. Because Pandit Nehru fought for his ideals, he spent twelve years in gaol; but, today, the world seeks to do him honour. Only a few days ago, wdien he visited Djakarta, he was greeted in the steets of that city by over 50,000 people. Yet, not so long ago, he was gaoled for subversive activities; and we have heard a great deal lately about activities so-called. The Opposition wishes to join with the Government in its plan to assist the unfortunate peoples of South and South East Asia, but only if the action proposed to be taken is inspired by a spirit of humanitarianism. We can help to raise the standard of living of those peoples by various means, including the provision of technical assistance and greater facilities for education. The honourable member for Chisholm rather decried the provision of assistance in that form. I do not despair of such proposals. The provision of technical equipment and facilities for technical training will do much more for the native peoples that we are anxious to help, whereas assistance in the form of monetary grants would not be effective because the money could be expended without the peoples whom it was intended to assist knowing that such grants had ever been made. Assistance in the form of physical things is most effective particularly when 90 per cent, of these native peoples cannot read or write. When they see evidence of the assistance provided, they realise that something is being done to help them. In that way we shall also do much to stem the tide of communism which thrives under conditions of unrest, discontent and unemployment. However, any assistance that is provided, for ulterior motives will not be effective. In this matter we must be guided by the highest humanitarian ideals. The Opposition, when it was in office, persistently upheld the United Nations organization, which has already achieved much to end unrest in various countries, including. Indonesia and Israel. I do not decry conferences of the kind for which the Minister is an advocate, but I realise the difficulties that confront such conferences in dealing with the problems of the nature of those that exist in India, South Africa, Burma or Ceylon. Excluding Australia and New Zealand, Ceylon is the most empire-minded country in the Eastern hemisphere. It is useless merely to shout about the curse of communism. We must face up to the difficulties. If we can help the peoples of the south and south-east Asian countrieswe should do all in our power to do so, but, to repeat the view expressed by Pandit Nehru, wo shall succeed only if" we capture the spirit of the people whom we are trying to help and do not takeaction of a kind that carries with it the conviction that our real objective is toprotect certain interests in these countries so that they can continue to make a lot of dollars out of rubber, tin or otherproducts. That was the impression that was given to these native peoples in the past. To-day, we musf convince them that we are awake to the great social misery that exists in their countries about which no one bothered hitherto. Wemust convince those peoples that our only objective in helping them is to do something for humanity and for Christianity because we believe that only by working to achieve the ideals of Christianity can we improve the lot of the less fortunatepeoples of the world. Mr BEENAED CORSEB, (Wide Bay) [10.14] - I compliment the Minister for External Affairs (Mr Spender) upon thestatement that he has made to the Houseon the subject of international affairs. I listened with some interest to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Chifley). His remarks were in keeping with the statements that we heard from him for years when he was Prime Minister and led a government that must shoulder much of the blame for the problems that have arisen in south-east Asian countries and elsewhere and with which we now seek to deal. If this problem has been handled by the Chifley Government in the manner in which it has been handled by the present Government, many of the troubles that now confront us would not exist. The Leader of the Opposition has said that communism has nourished in those countries where there is grave discontent among the people. I do not agree with him. The tenets of communism are propagated in every country of the world, including Australia,, irrespective of the social conditions of its people. The right honourable gentleman made an appeal for world action to counter the menace of communism. He views the problem as though it were not merely a matter of one country being determined to dominate the world. Australia has always been vitally concerned about the welfare of its near neighbours. It is a great pity that the Leader of the Opposition and his deputy did not show more interest in the peoples of the eastern races when they had the opportunity to do so. They must have known that the safety of British ancl Australian lives depended upon the maintenance of peace and contentment among the peoples of the East. It is lamentable that the Leader of the Opposition in this National Parliament should descend to such a low level in criticising the actions of this Government, which has done more in the short period that it has been in office to promote the welfare of the peoples of South and South East Asia than his Government did throughout the long period it was in office. It is regrettable that he should attempt to fan the fires of hate by stating that the land in the Philippines is owned by only 1 per cent, of the people of that country. Such an inaccurate statement is in line with the propaganda disseminated by the Communists with the object of fomenting discontent. Ifr. Bernard Oorser.

Speaker: Mr CLAEEY
Title: AIRCRAFT ACCIDENT NEAR SOUTH
text: Bendigo) [10.27] - I regret that the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Corser) completely misunderstood the purport of the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Chifley). The right honourable gentleman said, in effect, that communism has made its greatest progress and brought about the direst results in countries in which the living standards of the people are very low, and social discontent, is rife. That statement is perfectly true. I invite the honourable member for Wide Bay to compare the conditions in countries in which communism has made rapid, headway with those that exist in countries in which communism has been kept at bay. If he did so, he would find that, in the TJnited States of America, Sweden, Norway, and the British Commonwealth, in which the conditions of life are good, communism has made least progress, but that in the countries in which the greatest poverty and misery exists, communism has flourished and is still flourishing. I agree with the honourable gentleman that the statement by the Minister for External Affairs (Mr Spender) is most valuable, and has been of great assistance not only to the members of this House but also to the Australian community. It reveals that great problems are facing the countries of South and South-East Asia, that they must have some effect on Australia, and that they have resulted from unfavorable social and economic conditions among the peoples concerned. These conditions,.as he has very rightly [035] pointed out, should be corrected and it is the duty of all the more advanced nations to assist in some way or other in providing the necessary impetus for the rectification of the conditions that have placed South and South-East Asia in the very difficult position in which they are today. That is very necessary because those areas, despite the fact that they constitute only one-fifth of the earth's surface, contain half the world's population. The conditions that have gradually developed in those countries since 1945, moving down through China, India and Burma into Malaya and Indonesia, show that during the period in which we had hoped that the nations of the world would be able to recover from the disastrous effects of the war, those countries have encountered difficulties and problems that up to the present they have not been able to solve. This conference has produced constructive suggestions regarding steps that might be taken to improve the conditions of the peoples of those countries. I consider that it is essential that certain matters should be pointed out to honourable members. In every one of these countries we find similar difficulties that might be summed up in the facts that populations are growing, standards of living are deteriorating, general illiteracy and primitive methods of production exist, and production is low. In addition those countries suffer from poor hygiene and a very high mortality rate. Since the war a number of Asian countries have attained self-government, and as a result have realized the backward nature of their own economic and social development more clearly than tliey did before. They have found it necessary, in co-operation with other countries and among themselves to try to find ways and means of making life better in their own particular spheres. That is a very difficult undertaking because most of those countries are mainly agricultural. Their economic life depends upon the soil. In India, which might be taken as typical of most Asian countries, 70 per cent, of the population depend upon agriculture for their livelihood, and only 11 per cent, secure a livelihood from industry or handicrafts. However, in spite of the fact that such a large proportion of the people of India work on the land it is rapidly becoming evident that because of the general unsettlement of conditions and the internal unrest in that countiy it is unable to provide all the food that is required for its own people or any surplus for export to other Asian countries that would enable them to meet their difficulties. Because of these factors the Minister's recommendations regarding the provision of economic, technical and nnanciai aid to Asian countries hecome understandable and we can realise that unless effect is given to them the position may become more desperate, with very disastrous reactions upon this country. One aspect of the matter that has not beendealt with during this debate and that I consider all honourable members should note is that the whole responsibility of trying to solve these internal difficulties of Asian countries does not fall alone upon the United Nations or upon a conference of members or of other bodies that may be called to discuss them. In 1944, at the International Labour Organization conference that was held at Philadelphia, the whole subject of assistance to Asiatic and South Asiatic countries was given very earnest consideration. That conference was called for the purpose of determining the policy to be adopted in regard to the improvement of the conditions of the masses in those countries following the conclusion of World War II., which was then raging. One of the decisions made was that it was necessary that the International Labour Organization should itself take steps to enable better conditions to operate in the backward countries of the world. Among other things it was determined that at the earliest possible moment regional conferences should be called in Asia and amongst the Asian peoples, so that the problems - of the Asian nations might be considered. That was an important decision because it meant that if such conferences were held under the auspices of the International Labour Organization the three constituent parties in the modern State would be asked to co-operate in order to deal with problems facing the Asian nations. As is well known, all the representation at the International Labour Organization Conference is of a Mr Clarey. tri-partite nature. It consists of representatives of governments, employers and workers of the participating nations. These three important constituents in the State meet together to consider the problems that are common to all of them and te make recommendations concerning how those problems might be overcome. The 1944 conference decided that the first regional conference should be a conference of the Asiatic countries that were represented at that conference. Those countries advanced the plea that the Asian countries that lie close to one another would have a mutual understanding of their common problems. They were entirely different from the problems found in the Western world. It was considered that if the delegations consisting of representatives of ' governments, employers and workers met something might be achieved that would improve the conditions of life of the Asian masses. The first regional conference convened by the International Labour Organization was held at New Delhi in 1947 and the very matters that have been the subject of considerable comment and explanation by the Minister for External Affairs were in fact discussed there by the representatives of employers, governments and workers. At that preliminary conference these matters were set down for discussion. The necessary machinery was put into operation to ascertain the facts in connection with the proposals advanced, and arrangements were made for a further conference to be held. The preliminary conference covered increased production, development of agriculture, the development of handicrafts, the formation' of co-operative societies, social security, recruiting and training of workers, wages and the protection of women and young workers. Subsequently, in February of this year, following the conference of British Commonwealth ministers held at Ceylon, a second regional conference to deal with the conditions in Asia was convened by the International Labour Organization and was held at Ceylon. It was attended by representatives of the same number of nations as had attended the New Delhi Conference in 1947. Eighteen nations were represented ranging from Indonesia in the south to China in the north. One hundred and twenty-one delegates from those countries represented their governments, employers and workers. They were able to make more progress in connection with the problems that affected the countries that we are now discussing. That conference realized that if the best results were to be obtained for the improvement of the productive capacity of the Asian nations, illiteracy had to be wiped out. The honourable member for Chisholm (Mr Kent Hughes) stressed very rightly what was being done in Malaya in regard to education, but that position does not operate in all the other countries that were associated with the International Labour Conference at Ceylon. The delegates to that conference realized that the problem of illiteracy must be tackled in such a manner as to enable people to get at least some elementary education without which the development of handicrafts and industry would be impossible. Decisions were - made on such important matters as the establishment of wage-fixing machinery, measures designed to improve Asian Labour Inspection services, international action to stimulate development of the co-operative movement as a means to furtlier economic development, measures designed to assist Asian countries to make full use of theii man-power through the organization and development of employment services, and the provision of vocational and technical training. The request was made that the governing body of the International Labour Organization should soon convene a further conference to discuss conditions affecting Asian seamen. I think that the essential point in connection with that conference is that the people who are to provide the machinery to increase the production rate and the standards of living, and to do the other things that are necessary to overcome the internal discontent in those countries, have taken the required action and have passed the necessary resolutions. Governments and organizations of employers and workers are committed to carrying out a policy that is designed to briug about internal improvements. A continuation of that kind of action is the quickest way of overcoming the difficulties in Asiatic countries: I conclude by saying that the decisions at that conference were real and practical. I agree with the honourable member for Chisholm that in giving technical aid of some description to increase production in these countries it is impossible to have them jump from lowly methods of production to highly mechanized methods. To the Asian farmer who has to standon his plough in order to break the soil, the provision of tractors and other highly mechanized equipment is of no use at all. The thing to do is to provide him with better hand tools, with a spade to use instead of his hands, with rakes and hoes to break up the soil, with p'umps instead of bucketsand cans. By such means we can rapidly improve the productivity of the Asian countries. Better seed could be made available to Asian farmers and they could be taught how to use and preserve the soil. That is what j required to meet s the problems of production and low standards of living and to enable Asian farmers to get the best results from their toil. If the Asian people, in cooperation with one another, do their best to assist themselves, if thÂ© highly developed nations make available to the governments of those countries the technical advice that can assist them in big projects, and if the efforts that are now being made to overcome illiteracy are continued, in a very short space of time a lot of the difficulties that now confront the South Asian and Asian people will probably be overcome because of the application of common sense to the problems of those countries by the nations that help them. text: East Sydney) [10.47] There was a discussion in this House recently on a matter that was raised hy the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr MCDonald), concerning a broadcast which had been made by a Mr Erank Browne. At that time. I asked the Postmaster-General (Mr Anthony) what action he proposed to take in regard to employment by the Australian Broadcasting Commission of Frank Browne as a writer of script. I notice that no such action appears to have been taken, because in the programme from 2FC-2NA on the 13th June, at 8 o'clock, there is an item that is listed as, " The race called the Derby: Feature by Frank Browne ". I should like the Minister to say whether Mr Browne is presenting this item in completion of a contract that he has with the Australian Broadcasting Commission or whether he is being favourably considered for work of this type. In view of the charge that was made against Mr Frank Browne by the honourable member for Corangamite, and in view of many other things that could be said by honourable members regarding his activities, T suggest that he is not a and proper person to be employed by the Australian Broadcasting Commission or any other government department, and I ask the Minister in charge of the House (Mr Spender) to take the matter up with the Postmaster-General in order to see whether he can obtain a statement on it. I wish also to speak on the subject of housing. From time to time, when disastrous floods take place, appeals are made for some assistance to be given to the persons affected and, quite properly, the governments of the country, and the Commonwealth Government in particular, assist in alleviating their distress. When a very few people are affected there does not seem to be the same agitation to render assistance, and my appeal is on behalf of a number of people who have been affected by the recent heavy rains in the metropolitan area of Sydney. These unfortunate people, who have been living in emergency accommodation, such as tents in coastal camping areas, particularly in the Narrabeen district, were completely washed out by the recent torrential rains and an appeal was made by the New South Wales police to the New Soutli Wales Housing Commission for some assistance in temporarily housing them until they could be provided for elsewhere. The police were informed by the housing authorities that no emergency accommodation was available. Quite a number of families are the affected and, no doubt, in other areas the position is just as desperate. Many of tliem have young families and I want to know whether this Government will make accommodation available for housing them by treating the present situation as one of emergency. No doubt there are militaiy establishments at which some accommodation could be made available and blankets and warm clothing could be provided as well. Unless something is done for these people they will be unable to extricate themselves from their desperate plight. The police have been unable to give aid and the State housing authorities say that they are unable to help. The only authority remaining to be approached is the Commonwealth. Surely some accommodation could be fit made available in the service establishments of the Commonwealth. Victoria Barracks at Paddington has a great deal of accommodation, much of which, 1 understand, is used for storing records which could be shifted elsewhere so that the space thus occupied might be used to accommodate these families that are in sueh distressing circumstances. However, it is not my purpose to advise the Government as to where the accommodation can be found because I am not in possession of sufficient information on that subject to enable me to do so. Itshould be the responsibility of some authority to help these people. As they have failed to obtain assistance elsewhere I want to know what the Commonwealth is prepared to do for them. Dr DONALD CAMERON . (Oxley) [10.51] - I consider that before the House adjourns something should be said concerning certain honours and awards that the conferring of which has been announced today. If I mention any names in that list, it is not for the purpose of comparing them in any way with others, but merely to emphasize my remarks. Ex-servicemen will feel considerable satisfaction that the names of the people concerned should have appeared in the list. By way of example, I refer to such distinguished gentlemen as Lieutenant General Sir H . C. H . Eobertson, who has maintained and enhanced the prestige of this country by his command of the British Commonwealth Occupation Eorce in Japan; Lieutenant-General Sir Stanley Savige, whose campaign on Bougainville was a_very considerable feat of arms, and who rendered distinguished service there and elsewhere; and Brigadier Sir Neil Hamilton Fairley, whose researches into the problem of malaria were responsible for the fact that the Australian Army was able to continue fighting in malarious areas and whose work in the experimental station that was established at Cairns was a great contribution not only to military medicine, but also to the world's knowledge of malaria. The contributions made by Sir Neil Hamilton Fairley were so notable in this case that he is now Professor of Tropical Medicine in the University of London. Malaria, I point out, kills more people every year than does any other infectious disease in the world, not even excepting tuberculosis. Above all, I should like to mention the award to Field-Marshal Sir Thomas Blarney, who is a distinguished soldier of two world wars. Many of us ex-servicemen, as time rolled on, experienced a feeling of disappointment- I might almost say dismay-becaus e no recognition had been accorded to the distinguished soldier who commanded the Australian Army from the time the nation's life was at stake until final victory was won. I know that the reward of a soldier does not consist of, and is not measured by, the honours and awards that he may receive. The reward of a soldier, I suggest, is the knowledge that he has performed his duty to his country and made his contribution to the preservation of the national life, and if there is any soldier in Australia who can feel entitled to that reward it is Sir Thomas Blarney. It is a right as well as a tradition of our race, that at the end of a war - and I point out that the last war was the greatest in all history-som e mark of national esteem should be accorded to the leaders of the armed forces. In his case that has now been done, and the act of doing it has given satisfaction to all ex-servicemen. Not only does this award mark the nation's gratitude to a distinguished soldier, but also it recalls, if, indeed, there were any need to recall it, the memory of all those who served under his command and whose mortal remains now lie in the cemeteries of the western desert, in Greece, Crete, and in the jungles and forests of the islands north of Australia. It recalls, also, all those in this country who bear in their bodiesfchemarks and infirmities of war. "Whilst we can express our appreciation of the distinction that has been accorded to Field-Marshal Blarney, I invite the attention of the Minister at the table (Mr. Spender) to the desirability of some national recognition of the services of other military leaders. We owe a great debt also to the leaders of the naval and air forces of the Commonwealth. I have in mind, too, another distinguished soldier, who served for two periods as Chief of the Australian General Staff, and who commanded the First Australian Army when it was fighting in New Guinea, New Britain and Bougainville, and when, T consider, the Australian military effort reached its peak. That Army fought in military circumstances of great novelty and considerable magnitude, and I suggest that national figures such as its leader should not be allowed to pass finally into the shadows without some mark of esteem from the nation that they served so well.  associate myself with the remarks of the honourable member for Oxley (Dr Donald Cameron). As most honourable members are aware, the Labour party is opposed to the conferring of military and civil honours. However, when such honours are conferred, I am always prepared to pay my tribute to the recipients. On this occasion, so far as I am aware from a rapid perusal of the honours list, the awards are well merited. A regrettable feature of the practice of conferring honours is that, inevitably, some deserving individuals are omitted from the list because they are forgotten or overlooked. As far as military honours are concerned, I regret that they cannot be made to every member of the forces. However, I rose principally to express my gratification at the promotion of General Blarney to the rank of Field Marshal. I have always considered that General Blarney had a profound knowledge of tactics and strategy and the capacity to put that knowledge to very good use. In my opinion, during the 1914-18 war, there was a long period of time during which men were needlessly sacrificed. I have always believed that from the time General Blarney became Chief of Staff of the Australian Army Corps under Sir John Monash there was a great improvement of tactics and strategy, with a con- worthy. sequent saving of many lives. I believe, too, that General Blarney's military knowledge played a great part in "World War II . For those reasons, I consider that the honour that has been conferred upon this distinguished soldier is well merited and will meet with full approval.

I do not think that this debate should be allowed to conclude without some reference being made to the remarks of the honourable member for East Sydney (Mr Ward) about the Australian Broadcasting Commission's use of scripts written by Frank Browne. About Frank Browne's journalistic work, I have nothing to say. I have occasionally seen copies of his news sheet and, from what I have read in it, I see no reason to attempt to dispute the remarks of honourable members on this side of the House about his standard of journalism. However, the honourable member for East Sydney has suggested that, merely because he has asked questions and expressed opinions in this House concerning Frank Browne's standard of journalism, the Australian Broadcasting Commission should immediately cease broadcasting his work. That, I believe, would amount to an unwarranted interference with the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. As an independent statutory body, the Australian Broadcasting Commission has a right and a duty to carry out its responsibilities in its own way. The suggestion that it should be immediately influenced by a question asked, or an opinion expressed by an honourable member of this House is, to my mind, quite unreasonable.
